text: hey everyone i am very excited to be giving my first in-person talk in almost two years
so today i want to share with you some of my recent work around how do we get like hci
human computer interaction professionals and ai engineers to sort of collaboratively design human ai
experiences so if you think about it in the last 20 years or so we've gotten a lot better at
incorporating human centered design within software engineering workflows not not ai but like regular
software engineering we've created new roles uh expertise develop tools and
design processes to kind of really drive software design based on human needs
user experience designers who are kind of trained at understanding human behavior and usability and designing
graphical user interfaces they usually work with end users to identify their goals and needs and challenges
these designers then create software design solutions to address those needs and challenges and hand them off
to engineers who are experts at writing software code to make it a bit more concrete let's
imagine designing a phone unlock user experience by taking a human-centered approach it's a very simple example that
kind of helps you understand the message so if you are a designer you would first try
to identify when where and how people are using their phones and what their security concerns are you will then
derive a set of design needs like you know the user experience should be like quick to unlock and it should require
low cognitive effort to remember you can then prototype a bunch of interface alternatives such as a numeric
key code an alphanumeric password or a patent based unlock and we have really sophisticated prototyping tools that
would allow designers to create these high-fidelity click-through interactive prototypes without writing any code
and as a designer you can also like evaluate these different alternatives with potential end users and you may
determine that numeric key code is the best option at this point as a designer you have
fully defined the user experience to unlock the phone including the interface design interaction behavior style guide the
length of the password and all of that and you can hand this off to an engineer who will then build to those
specifications and over the years we've kind of optimized this process for efficiency
through things like separation of concerns and modular design that the interaction between designers and
engineers is largely that of coordination and handoff
now imagine designing an ai powered phone unlock user experience one that uses facial identification to
authenticate users the interface design itself is quite simple and it consists of a blank screen
with a single like a lock icon and such an interface this i experience has to support diverse users in varied contexts
of use now unfortunately unlike conventional software design designers cannot fully
specify the user experience at the interface level alone the design extends beyond the user
interface into the design of different ai subcomponents as well as in thinking about the training data
and because ai requires writing meta programs to learn from data or examples engineers cannot build software to exact
specifications which means like the coordination handoff approach is no longer viable for
designing ai-powered applications in fact if you look at like recent
literature in the hci community like they've surfaced a number of challenges where designers find it really hard to
understand ai capabilities prototyping ai interfaces is really challenging they cannot use like this fail fast fail
often approach to prototype api powered interfaces the current machine learning workflows
don't really take into account like the data needs for these machine learning applications and engineers often treat
data as non-technical and lastly engineers and designers have different
priorities and incentives which makes it really it introduces a lot of friction for them to collaborate at this
intersection so in the last couple of years i've been looking at how might we support
designers and engineers to kind of work together to co-design these human-centered ai experiences from the
ground up and today i'll share with you three different projects that i've been
working on in answering these questions the first few are a bit more qualitative more formative need finding type of work
and then i'll share with you a prototyping tool that i developed for designing ai powered applications
yeah so the the the first project is about um we were looking at how like how
do industry practitioners currently build human ai systems now
companies like microsoft google and apple have been putting out all these design guidelines for building human ai
applications and ideally these guidelines represent best practice advice based on you know current
implementation within these organizations so we use these guidelines as a starting point to kind of understand like you
know how are practitioners you know putting these guidelines into practice how are they operationalizing them within their software design workflows
so we collected a total of 280 design guidelines and did an affinity diagramming exercise to kind of identify
what are the key components and tasks involved in building human ai applications
the good news is the guidelines do talk about centering people not just in the user interface and interaction design
but also centering them in the design of ai behavior as well as designing the training data needs
so with regard to data these guidelines prescribe that we consider people when we're thinking about data needs how we
collect data how we label data as well as user privacy and security so
an example would be like we should consider what information would a human need if they had to perform a task
similarly in terms of ai behavior these guidelines recommend that we need to think about people when we are designing
like the ai's behavior the assumptions and how we implement those behavior thinking about human
centered ways to measure performance of these machine learning models evaluating them with diverse users and thinking
about things like learnability and so on so an example would be when designing
automation we should consider if a human were to perform a task what assumptions they would make and lastly these guidelines prescribe
that when we're building these uh ai experiences we need to think about like you know what kind of input should we
expect users to provide how should we present the outputs back to the end user and how do we integrate ai into human
tasks and also in dealing with ai's uncertainties like explainability
feedback and failures so one of the the guidelines talks about
thinking whether to automate or augment based on how well the ai performs
and across all these layers the goal is really to see that we align these experiences with people's
task models that is how they perform the task today their expectation models about what they should expect the ai to
do for them or what they expect ai to do for them and the interaction model or how they expect to interact with these
ai sub-components so using this model as a guide we did an
interview study with 21 industry practitioners from 14 different organizations
participants included like software engineers ux designers product managers data scientists and research scientists
we recruited them through our network and then through like snowball sampling each interview lasted about 60 minutes
and we we coded this data using uh standard qualitative coding methods in vivo coding and then we conducted this
memory activity over an extended period to kind of synthesize the findings
before i talk about the key findings i just want to give you an overview of like the organization structures so
within larger organizations you usually have these core ai research teams who
typically work on like foundational ai research and coming up with new ai capabilities and they may also have like
core ux teams and in-house legal and domain experts and oftentimes these large organizations
also have these bridge teams who essentially like take the outputs of like korea research and create demos and
prototypes for tech transfer to product teams so up until this point like you don't
have like product users involved in any of the decisions that go on here and then larger organizations have
multiple product teams smaller organizations may have just one product team and each product team has typically
has like a manager back in front and developers as well as ux people
and all of these organizations work with third-party or external
entities like for smaller organizations who don't have in-house ai developers
they make use of third-party ai services but they also like all these organizations make use of data
annotators university interns as well as test users
so i'll talk about in the in the interest of time i'm going to talk about like two findings from the study
the first is that these the the design engineering boundary sort of poses specific challenges to this
cross-disciplinary nature of human ai design so with conventional software the user
interface acts as sort of this natural seam for designers and engineers to coordinate and given their differences
in expertise you know boundary abstractions and separation of concern is actually favored to make the process more
efficient that is designers don't typically share like low level details about their interview notes or
observation notes or their prototype alternatives with engineers similarly engineers are not required or they don't
share like how they implement the software or details about the code and framework with designers
while this is great for conventional software design it becomes problematic for designing human ai experiences
specifically the abstraction boundaries between designers and engineers kind of introduces this knowledge blindness that
is when creating these core ai capabilities engineers don't have a full understanding of the human task model or
their interaction model or what they expect the ai to do and what ends up happening is they end
up building all these capabilities that may not really align with what people want in this example on
analyzing videos one of the participants says like you know people would just go off and bear directions get obsessed
with trying to identify guns or something that really wasn't important to what we were doing
similarly uh the designers experience technology blindness that is they they
don't fully understand like the capabilities and limitations of these different ai sub components and there's
either like under trust or over trust in what ai can or cannot do an example would be like the the twitter
image auto cropping example where there was no interface effort and for them to manually crop
these images and as you can see here with conventional software the designers
are used to building like these screen to screen flows but with ai the probability space is much more widely
open they need to understand the failure cases the confidence and how to deal with confidence scores and thresholds
second because of these boundaries designers and engineers tend to work rather
independently which which leads to sort of like committing or concretizing their design
choices even before they align the ai and ux and this leads to a lot of friction at the boundaries
so with like i mentioned in the earlier example of the phone unlock thing the designer
creates these final specifications before handing off to the engineers but that becomes problematic in this case so
one of the engineers comments about this saying like you know they would just hand off these design documents to the engineer and say implement this it felt
particularly extraneous when it got very granular and it was not the best medium to describe the desired behavior
similarly engineers also like you know finalize you spend months building these machine learning models and then go to
the designers and say hey can you find a place to integrate this into your product and that doesn't work either so
in this case like um i think the team was working on some kind of a taxonomy for classifying videos so they would
build this whole thing and go to the designer and say hey find a place to put this into like a voice assistant in this
case so they have their own taxonomy on what kind of information they're looking for but for users it doesn't work
response and the third problem is like these boundaries rustic collaboration really
because designers and engineers don't know the process about like designers don't understand the engineering process
engineers don't know a lot about like the design process which means it's hard for them to identify opportunities to
work with each other or to give inputs or collaborate so in one example we had a designer say
like it seemed very odd to me that as designers we were not invited to the data annotation sessions so we had to
invite ourselves just to talk to the domain experts for engineers that approach us more like the machine is going to figure it out we
could be talking about health or elephants in a circus and it's all the same to them
and the same problem happens on the other side as well where designers have their own priorities and are focused on
like products and end users which means they're not incentivized to really work on these
core ai effort that goes on so what ends up happening in a lot of
these organizations is an ai first design workflow that is you have machine
learning engineers and researchers creating these new ai capabilities and then asking designer product teams to
integrate this into the product and as we've seen as an example in the gender shades paper if we discover after
the fact that these models don't work for certain subgroups of population not only will it require costly rework to
fix these issues but people are already harmed
so in in addition like we also saw that you know some teams yes
so in that case like are the gender shapes how would involving ux design earlier have solved
that problem versus just the engineers didn't do their job of making sure that the you know vision
systems they were doing worked across the population yes but uh also like thinking about the representativeness of
data that is something that ux teams could have supported them with but isn't this the thing we should expect
engineers to do independent of ux design uh i'm arguing no no yeah i'm saying
designers should be involved in efforts and i wouldn't argue that designers shouldn't be involved early in any
project but i also feel like there's some level that we should expect engineering to understand how technology is used
yeah um yeah i will i will get to this at a later point
so we also noticed that you know teams that were successful in actually doing this they practice deliberate leaky
abstractions at the boundaries that allow them to sort of collaborate and work with each other
and what i mean by that is rather than observing like these strict boundaries and separation of consents successful
teams created these a number of these ad hoc representational objects and shared it
with each other that would expose low level design and implementation details with each other and through these
abstraction leaks they were actually able to you know engage in like knowledge communication uh
design negotiation as well as even like co-design and evaluation
so leaky abstractions firstly like they alleviate knowledge blindness which i
mentioned earlier so in a lot of cases what we noticed were these designers rather than you
know doing the whole like user research to this final design specifications they
would create these initial envisioning visualizations of sorts and sketches and storyboards and share them
with the engineering team to kind of help them think about like you know how they should be planning out the ai
design space and similarly the the ai product teams
when they think about these new ai capabilities rather than waiting until the end they would uh usually this a
university intends to do this they create these small prototypes and then share them with the
designers and ask them to play around with it to kind of help them understand how machine learning can actually be beneficial in specific use cases so as
this person says like we got something tangible enough that we could go and actually talk to the designer and be like here's what we were thinking it
also broke the problem down such that the designers understand here's the benefit of where machine learning can be
applied and further these abstraction leaks promote design collaboration so instead
of people working on their respective designs and silo they can actually start to
bring in engineers in creating like these ui prototypes so in this example this designer was making like a wizard
of ours prototype of a model and then they worked with the data scientists to get the model output who also like
explained the reasoning behind these things how the different weights were set and how these productions happen and
they use this to kind of then share with end users to get their feedback
and similarly the engineers reported things like they find artifacts like storyboards very helpful
which is not true in like the previous case um so you know here is a situation
and like this is what should happen over the course of this interaction it's really useful to have back and forth
with people who are trained to think carefully about these experiences and lastly leaky abstractions support
evaluation of design like early on in the process before waiting until a final product is developed and
deployed so in this case we noticed instances in which like engineers would take like the outputs of machine
learning models as spreadsheets and then talk to either legal experts to kind of walk them through what's going on under
the hood or share these outputs with domain experts who would then like label whether like the outputs and
predictions are right or wrong and then they would use that feedback to kind of revise on their models
and these prototypes are also helpful in like evaluating the product with target
end users as well so they would create these different prototypes with uh you know
visualizations about explainability and then uh especially when they are like comparing different algorithms so in
this case they were working on this image based search system so they created around like 20 different versions of the
algorithm and each time they would create these explainable visualizations of the palettes with the original image
and the target and compare them uh or like get feedback from the end users
so in this way we saw like a number of these unconventional
you know boundary negotiation objects that were shared between designers and engineers throughout this ai workflow
to communicate about user needs for training data designers would create like qualitative code books and share
those with labelers and engineers or communicating user needs for behavior
where they would like i mentioned earlier share user scenarios low fetility prototypes
provide ground to data and usage reports and also invite the engineers into like user
evaluation so that they could see firsthand like what's going on similarly engineers also share things
like computational notebooks with designers to kind of help them play around with the data to kind of
assess it for like representativeness and so on or communicate model behavior
through these envisioning grey box prototypes share raw model outputs and create these
dashboards and they also shared like you know these prototypes that would allow designers to
kind of evaluate and gather feedback on their own
so based on these findings we see that leaky abstractions offer sort of an alternative to an ai first design
workflow that is instead of first creating the ai and then like trying to integrate it to the product team what we saw that
successful teams are doing is like they would create fuzzy or partial specifications of both the ai and the ui
and then by sharing these artifacts through leaky abstractions with each other like the design decision and
design details they were able to collaboratively assess negotiate and revise their own design
for example like an engineer would create like a share like an evolving ai behavior with
the design team who would then evaluate that end users and provide feedback and
not committing to the design at this early stage makes it more pliable for collaboration and inputs
and across like these successive iterations more and more aspects of the design becomes finalized and the need for
leakiness reduces and in the final stages you have a product which is aligned across ai ui and humans
so with this first uh work we kind of saw that like instead of yes
you know in your first abstraction where you just have this complete line you have design and engineering
um when you add in ai i'm wondering if another issue becomes just more communication
because i've noticed in some companies instead of just having back end engineering and front engineer now you also have a machine learning team and
yeah and so the ui people like a lot of things are like oh the back end people say that's the
machine learning people's job and the machine learning people say oh no it's the back end people so there's like this more kind of passing the buck which is
harder for the ux did you see yeah this is a bit of a simplified representation but this applies to many
different roles including like data scientists domain experts like in-house like clinicians especially like in
healthcare application and like the the point i wanted to make was like uh instead of like one a workflow which is
more linear where one person comes to the design and like throws it over the wall now you have different people like
sharing the kind of design decisions they're making which allows them to sort of realign or adjust their own design
and sort of more collaboratively rather than coordinating
so one of the limitations of this first project was because of nda reasons like these companies couldn't give us a lot
of low level details about like what they were doing or how this collaboration happened so
to get a better sense of like what's going on through these like shared artifacts we did a second study where
we brought in people to the lab and asked them to work together to design an ai application
so this was an in-lab design study with around 20 participants we had like 10 ui
designers 10 ai engineers and they worked in pairs to kind of
come up with a solution to a design problem and we conducted 10 sessions in total
we gave them a very simple problem we told them like you know can you build an ai powered application to declutter the
photo album the problem domain is simple enough that everyone understands like we said like you know people are taking lots and lots
of photos on their phones not all of them are useful so can you find a way to like use ai to declutter this and also
like computer vision and image data offers like this rich design space to think about how to solve this problem
and based on the findings from the first study about like sharing these um
user data and user personas we created a set of what we're calling data personas
where we have like these four different personas about an artist a parent
an instagram influencer and a corporate traveler but we also gave them like these um the last 15 photos taken by
each of these people to kind of help them think about like how they might declutter the photo album
and again we use the design guidelines that these companies are putting up to develop a protocol this is a very
simplified version but the paper has of the full details the idea was that they would first work together to brainstorm
ways in which ai can support decluttering the photo album then they brainstormed how they would
implement those behaviors uh using like ai including things like deciding
features and was that a question no uh and then they would prototype the
user uh interface for ai and specify the model apis between the interface and the model's inputs and outputs and then
designed for ais uncertainties including like error handling explainability failure and expectations
we we use qualitative coding to analyze this data so
the main finding i want to share with you is around this idea of like the the data we gave with each of the person as
that is the images they acted as this content common ground for designers and engineers to collaborate
they both have like different domain and expertise they have different processes
they follow and different things they design but then we saw that this end user data from each of the personas
acted as like an anchor point for them to ideate on these designs what we're calling as like data probes
as a tool for design and what i mean by that is like starting with this idea of like ai and the
abstract like we know i told them what ai behavior we want we didn't tell them like um filter images that are not high
quality or any of that we just told them like use the ai to declutter the photos so using this individual data points
from each of the personas they started generating user scenarios about like why
um people may have cluttered photo albums and using those scenarios they kind of thought about different ai
behaviors like you know when when we should detect and delete the photo like as soon as they capture
it at a later point of time should we aggregate it and things like that
so in this example like you know the parent persona like he's taken multiple duplicate photos of us fidgety kids and
like so they talk about like any i identify duplicate photos and find the best one to keep
and then the engineer goes like yes we can cluster images based on similarity so once you have this behavior that you
want in this case like identifying say duplicate photos then you need to think about how you're going to implement like
what does duplicate mean for different personas so to do that again like using the scenarios and the data points these
teams engaged in what i'm calling cognitive walkthroughs with the data and ai behavior to define these uh specific
implementation details so in this case um they talk about like can i figure out if
there is an image that is significantly blurrier and then delete those like so once you have these duplicate photos then maybe some kind of ranking by
quality like blurriness lighting uh they even talk about like eyes closed uh face
and object detection and so on and they also use these data points to identify things they should not do so in
one of the teams they were thinking about like deleting photos in which people were not smiling and then the designer goes like if someone had a
stroke and they're not smiling deleting those photos would be bad and then the engineer says like you know the model might predict that she's not smiling
because of missing two of the braces [Applause] and once you have this implementation the next thing is to determine like what
inputs should be provided and what outputs uh you should return to the interface and they
they brainstormed on like what the api should look like by creating user interface prototypes based on these
implementation again this was an iterative process where the designers would actually use the thumbnail images
we gave them for each of the personas so instead of using like uh placeholder text and images we asked them to use the
actual data and creating these prototypes so here they kind of identify like you know if they had a large cluster of
photos can we cluster them based on the reasons and then they start to think about explainability and like how do we
assign a reason for why your photo is being deleted and the engineer kind of explains uh how it works internally and
like how do we assign different ways to different regions and should we return just the top
reason for deleting a photo or not so based on these findings we propose this
initial process model for co-creating ai experiences now rather than like an ai
first or a ui first workflow the this model kind of distributes agency between designers and engineers
designers can use their data personas their ai infused scenarios expectation
models and interface prototype to shape the ai's design and implementation and
api without having technical details and then the our approach also shifts sort of the
engineer's mindset towards a more proactive engagement and human centered design process
and then using the individual data points teams can engage in like divergent design thinking and mutually constrained
convergence towards a solution
now uh the the the approach that we used in this initial session is fine for like you know the first uh brainstorming kind
of session but as the the fidelity of the data and the complexity of the model increases as people start building they
can no longer use this pen and paper approach but then like the model that we propose can be used to think about like
what kind of tools people might need and supporting these different collaborations at different stages of the development process
so i'm going to present you like one example where we built this prototyping tool based on the findings from this lab
study as i mentioned like prototyping with
real data and machine learning models allow the designers to sort of experience the ai's output and
capabilities firsthand as they are building this but if you look at conventional ui prototyping tools they kind of look like
this which is essentially like a closed box uh view but you only put in like placeholder text and images and so on
and if the designers are going to like you know explore the model on their first hand or see what the outputs look
like they may have to work with different tools for model exploration and evaluation
so with prototype our intent was to see how we can like combine this model exploration
user interface prototyping and evaluation within a single workflow that we're calling model inform prototyping
and we developed this tool called proto ai to support this prototyping workflow and i'll give you a
quick walkthrough of this tool at a high level the tool has four main tabs uh the
first tab is a collection of machine learning models and services and then you have this data tab where you can
like gather user inputs and data and like run the model with those data as part of your prototyping process and
then you have the the standard ui prototyping tab and then there's a tab
for evaluating your different prototypes let me walk you through this tool by
taking this very simple example of imagine you're building an application where you input an image and then
the the model classifies and outputs a label for that this is similar to like a lot of applications we see
uh with things like the birder app where you can recognize species of birds by inputting
an image so to build to prototype this experience
the designer would first go and select the image classification model and go to the data tab
here they can upload like a csv file of birds they have already collected along
with some ground true data and using this input they can actually run the model
and over here the model returns like three different outputs with a different confidence score for each label
now once they have this they can then go to the ui tab and start to incorporate like this the input data that they
collected along with the model output directly in their prototyping process so you have the the standard user
interface controls like a text box and label and things like that but you also have this data elements tab
where you can you know drop in like the photo of the actual bird and also like the label that the model retained
and once you do this you can
if you go to the data previews tab now you see what the interface looks like
for all of the input data that you had in the data tab and because you supplied
ground truth label proto ai automatically tags erroneous instances uh with errors which you can go and like
debug and analyze so in this case i think they're like three instances where the label that the model returned does
not match the label that the designer inputted that's ground truth
then now okay one thing i forgot to mention was like the labels that had errors the confidence scores were less than 60.
so now what they can do is they can start to oh actually yes so what the designer is doing here
is they also add the confidence code and they can and this is meant for them to debug so that they can go look at like
what's going on in these areas instances and this is where like the confidence
score for instances for the confidence score is less than 60 like the the model is it doesn't perform very
well or it's an error so now they can go and start to implement like mixed initiative design where
they can create a new interface state and add a condition where if the classification accuracy is like less
than 60 then you show this new state
so over here instead of just showing one label they can return all of the labels but also let the end user enter their
own label if they choose to
and with this if you go back to the previous tab now you can see that for instance which have like
errors it shows the new state so this kind of lets the designer play around with these different model outputs and set
thresholds and design different states of the interface for different types of uncertainties
and the designer can also like because they have the raw model output they can think about presentation aspects like
the api like what format should the model return the output should it be like a numerical score or whether do you
want to categorize it into high medium low so like these are things that the designer now has the flexibility to work
directly in based on what the interface needs are
so here i'm just you know adding a categorical column with high or low based on the
accuracy score and then in addition like you know if you have multiple data points on a
screen you can actually set the data context of the screen instead of having like one image over here i'm seeing all
of the images for a persona and we have these widgets that um
help you present like explainable output so like this is the best photo and these are the other three options and things
like that and
so in in summary like with protoei the designer can kind of leverage the full
advantage of like this vertical prototyping starting with raw data running the model output and evaluating
and designing iteratively they can supply their input data directly make use of the features and
model outputs if there is ground true data they can also use that to compare what the model
is doing and create these derived columns and using this they can kind of
facet the data in different ways and create different interface states based on different kinds of ai errors
and you can imagine something like this being used to evaluate the twitter's biased image cropping issue where the
designer could have taken like the saliency uh image model and then like inputted like different data with
different salient points and um test it for how well the algorithm performs or
if you want to do something like netflix movie recommendation you can think of supplying input data with different
personas and with different prior history of what kind of movies they watch and that can be used to sort of
prototype like learnability or learning over time and as i showed today you can think of creating like these mixed initiative
designs such as ambiguity widgets so
so far like in this talk i hope i've convinced you that rather than like an ai first approach where the engineer
just hands off this black box viewer close box model to the designer we can
you know rather take a more collaborative approach where the ai and ui components are sort of designed and
parallel um so building on this work i am interested in continuing to think
about like these different layers and this in this application stack uh the thing which i'm currently working
on is in thinking about like this idea of like data personas and how they can inform the training data for these
machine learning models and i know there's some paddle work going on at stanford around like data center ki i
still don't have a clear understanding of what that is but hopefully this will converge at some point
so right now if you look at machine learning textbook it's usually like acquire an initial data set and then there's some work on thinking about like
how do we document and like make the the data characteristics more transparent for other users or like in analyzing the
data we already have but what i'm interested in is and seeing how we can bring together all these
different people with different expertise to kind of define these data personas which can then inform the
training data needs and in the ai model and behavior space i'm very
much interested in thinking about how do we measure performance and this is a bit of a challenging problem
so currently if you think of like a speech recognition thing like the the way you measure performance is like word
at a rate but that doesn't really capture things like demographics sociocultural context resource
availability and policy and regulation so i'm interested in seeing how people with different expertise can come
together in defining fair performance metrics and what kind of tools do we need to support this collaboration
process and lastly i'm interested in extending some of the work which we've done in
proto ai to think about explainability and how do we bring in end users in identifying some of the
errors so in the current version where you have the data previous tab it's mainly the designer who looks for these
errors but in some cases the designers may not know i cannot say like whether it's an error or not so i'm interested
in seeing how we can bring in end users and what kind of explainable support they may need to
debug this design on their own but more broadly like in addition to
thinking about like how do we support expertise and collaboration and what kind of tools we may need i also do a
lot of work on designing these interactive intelligence systems using ai specifically for human
learning creativity and sense making right now i have started some new
conversations and projects around thinking about ai literacy for k through 12
learning in the wild that is learning outside classroom settings like how we can take what we know from best
practices and learning in the classroom and e-learning and apply them to more open-ended setting and i'm also interested in science communication
through visualizations and text so if you're a master student or an undergrad looking to work on research projects
please please please reach out to me and with that i will take questions
